comments.text:
According to NEP policy in the new education system, only three languages ‚Äã‚Äãshould be studied, and there is no requirement that Hindi should be among those three languages, / there is no imposition, good news.
Accordingly, Tamil is the mother tongue of the Tamil people here,  so Tamil has to be studied, English is the world language hence English also has to be studied, and I am interested in learning  Bengali a third language. According to the trilingual policy,  all the above three languages, Tamil, English and Bengali will be taught.
Another question is, will a student who wants to learn three languages ‚Äã‚Äã- Kannada, Malayalam, and English - is it possible to provide necessary facilities?
Yes , Hindi is not imposed among the three languages ‚Äã‚Äãchosen, but is this possible? For that to happen, there is a need to employ required competent teachers for each language.
Without teachers , it would be impossible to learn the third chosen language. Under such a situation finally it will be forced to learn Hindi in the end.
This is another form of imposition  of Hindi on non-Hindi speaking people, an indirect and deceptive act through the back door.

0:28 Cunning 3 ≥·µà Language:-
------------------------
- Why to learn any language,
- When not need throughout life,
- Unless you or parent want.
- English is taught in all schools.
- It can act as "tool" between states and 70-90% of countries.
- It is also taught in 90% of the asian/europian and 70% of the african/s.american countries.
- The time used for teaching Hindi or any other language, can be used to teach:-
1) In-depth of mothertongue.
2) Professional fluency in it.
3) Good spoken English.
4) More Science or Maths
5) More detailed History & Geography native to the state.
6) More Practicals, Arts and Games
- Learning little bits of 3+ languages, wont make a person expert in any of them, unless you live in the area where those languages are spoken¬†

comments.text:
I don‚Äôt know how much north indian people respect their mother tongue, but in Karnataka, we respect Kannada just like we respect our own mothers. It may be just a medium of communication for you, but for us, it‚Äôs our identity, our culture, and our pride.

India is a strong nation because of its diversity. It is a union of states ‚Äî not because of Hindi, but because of the unity among various languages, cultures, and traditions. Hindi is not the national language; it is just one of the many Indian languages. When Hindi is imposed on us, it feels like our own language, culture, and identity are under threat.

We don‚Äôt want to learn a third language. A two-language policy ‚Äî Kannada and English ‚Äî is enough for us. You may ask, why learn English, a British language, but not Hindi, an Indian language?

The truth is, India as a single political entity came into being only because of the British. Without them, this land would have remained a subcontinent of many kingdoms, cultures, and languages ‚Äî and that‚Äôs not something to be ashamed of. It‚Äôs our history.

We learn English because it opens global opportunities, helps us get better jobs, and improves our future. But what do we gain by learning Hindi? For most of us in the South, nothing. It doesn't help us professionally or socially. So why should we be forced to learn it?

If we don‚Äôt speak, preserve, and promote our language, who will? It's our responsibility to protect our language, not just for ourselves, but for future generations.

comments.text:
how can love for one‚Äôs country be authentic if it doesn‚Äôt include love for one‚Äôs roots‚Äîlanguage, culture, and community? When someone says ‚Äúcharity begins at home,‚Äù it‚Äôs not an act of selfishness‚Äîit‚Äôs a foundation. Likewise, embracing Kannada in Karnataka isn‚Äôt an act of defiance, it‚Äôs an act of identity, of rootedness, and from that rootedness comes the strength to embrace others.

The beauty and challenge of India lie in exactly this: unity through plurality. And that makes this tension deeply Indian‚Äîbecause few other countries carry the weight of so many languages, faiths, and traditions within one border. So yes, this friction is almost unique to India, but it‚Äôs also one of its greatest philosophical strengths: the constant balancing act between honoring the local and embracing the national.

Suggesting that not speaking Hindi makes someone unpatriotic is a narrow view of a vast and layered nation. In fact, it may be more patriotic to defend linguistic diversity‚Äîbecause that‚Äôs the soul of India. Just as justice starts next door, and charity at home, patriotism begins with love and respect for one‚Äôs own corner of the nation.

India, after all, didn‚Äôt become a republic of one identity‚Äîit became a federation of many. That‚Äôs not a flaw. That‚Äôs the design.

comments.text: Hindi is a colonial invention. The British standardized Hindustani which was a mix of Persian, Urdu (mixed with Arabic). The man behind standardization was a Scottish person John Gilchrist. They created Hindi for administering North India which had several languages Prakrit, Pali, Mythili, Awadhi, Khadi boli, Haryanvi, Rajasthani, etc. Second purpose was to print The Bible to convert North Indians en mass. They created Hindi because all the other languages used Devanagari script.  While in South Malayalam,  Tamil,  Kannada, Telugu didn't use a common script because of which standardization was not possible. So for administering South India/ erstwhile Madras Presidency the Britishers used English.
